sentences.sentence: Reward for risk-takersIt was refreshing to read Steven Hamilton's opinion piece ("Negative gearing is not a rort", April 26) logically dispelling the myth that negative gearing is a scam.Those who negatively gear a property, or any investment or business activity, are taking a risk - they are incurring a cash flow loss now on the hope that the investment will pay off in the future, with the eventual gain they receive on disposal of the investment or business being more than the losses they sustain throughout the holding period.While we have seen significant increases in property values in recent years, this has not always been the case.

You often need deep pockets to hold a property long enough to recover the purchase price, transfer duty and legal fees on acquisition, as well as sales commission, marketing and legal fees on sale, and still come out ahead before the ATO steps in for its cut.Many of these investors are ordinary mums and dads, hoping that their investment property will increase in value sufficiently so they can either provide for their family or support their retirement.
We need risk-takers - this should not be discouraged.Where to from here?

Negative gearing is only one policy lever and should not be looked at in isolation.We should take tax policy out of the hands of politicians and set up a separate organisation, similar to the RBA, to legislate all tax changes, including GST.

Ken Henry has the credibility and credentials to be the inaugural chairman.While we are reliant on politicians of the day to make changes to our taxation legislation, there will never be any government brave enough to make the fundamental shifts required to establish a tax base that will be fair and not specifically penalise any group into the future, as is evidenced by our existing system's reliance on PAYGW taxpayers.Michelle WilsonSpring Hill, QldDutton's dilemmaJacob Greber's column ("Dutton's atomic bet threatens Coalition chain reaction", April 26) highlights Peter Dutton's dilemma.No sooner had he bravely gone nuclear on the ABC's Insiders on April 21 than Nationals MP Warren Chester piped up "not in my backyard".While all this political posturing is going on, battery, wind and solar investors are bemused at best, scared off at worst.
Meantime the adults at the Australian Energy Market Operator are doing their darnedest to make wind, solar, hydro and gas work for the benefit of the nation.

No thanks to the pollies.Phil KreveldCaulfield, VicMusk seeks free speechThe Australian Financial Review's reporting on the battle between Elon Musk and the Australian political class is some of the most biased I have read.Freedom of speech is more important than anything any of us could do for Australia, including the prime minister.
There is no public safety without it.
There is no democracy without it.

It is the basis of our social cohesion.The political class, egged on by the media, is trying to rule over the global internet here, even as Mr Musk has unwillingly complied with Australian legal directives while the matter is before the courts.
Should videos of the September 11 attacks be censored?
Or the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki?

Those who censor rewrite history for malicious purpose.Stop and think for a second about the implications of what you are advocating.Remy ChadwickWagga Wagga, NSWTruth of super taxAll the heat and fury aimed at the Labor proposal to tax super fund balances above $3 million needs to be balanced against the reality as revealed in John Wasilev's column ("How will $3m super tax work when my balance rises and falls?
", April 27-28).The bottom line as detailed in the response is that a $4 million super fund will pay Division 296 tax of a tad over $4000 a year.
Using a conservative 7 per cent annual return, the $4 million fund should earn $280,000 a year.
Tax of $4000 on this annual income amounts to a rate of 1.4 per cent.

This is still significantly less than the tax a 20-year-old apprentice would pay on his or her meagre earnings.The fairer solution is to tax all retirement incomes at the same rate as other earnings after giving a generous allowance.Barry CookMitcham, SAA hollow promiseAt last some good news from Rowan Dean, who wrote: "Thanks to Anthony Albanese I am now out of a job" ("Seriously, Albo's meme theme is putting comedians out of work", April 27-28).
Alas, like all of Dean's oeuvre, it was an unamusing falsehood detached from observable reality.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Reward for risk-takersIt was refreshing to read Steven Hamilton's opinion piece ("Negative gearing is not a rort", April 26) logically dispelling the myth that negative gearing is a scam.Those who negatively gear a property, or any investment or business activity, are taking a risk - they are incurring a cash flow loss now on the hope that the investment will pay off in the future, with the eventual gain they receive on disposal of the investment or business being more than the losses they sustain throughout the holding period.While we have seen significant increases in property values in recent years, this has not always been the case. You often need deep pockets to hold a property long enough to recover the purchase price, transfer duty and legal fees on acquisition, as well as sales commission, marketing and legal fees on sale, and still come out ahead before the ATO steps in for its cut.Many of these investors are ordinary mums and dads, hoping that their investment property will increase in value sufficiently so they can either provide for their family or support their retirement. We need risk-takers - this should not be discouraged.Where to from here? Negative gearing is only one policy lever and should not be looked at in isolation.We should take tax policy out of the hands of politicians and set up a separate organisation, similar to the RBA, to legislate all tax changes, including GST. Ken Henry has the credibility and credentials to be the inaugural chairman.While we are reliant on politicians of the day to make changes to our taxation legislation, there will never be any government brave enough to make the fundamental shifts required to establish a tax base that will be fair and not specifically penalise any group into the future, as is evidenced by our existing system's reliance on PAYGW taxpayers.Michelle WilsonSpring Hill, QldDutton's dilemmaJacob Greber's column ("Dutton's atomic bet threatens Coalition chain reaction", April 26) highlights Peter Dutton's dilemma.No sooner had he bravely gone nuclear on the ABC's Insiders on April 21 than Nationals MP Warren Chester piped up "not in my backyard".While all this political posturing is going on, battery, wind and solar investors are bemused at best, scared off at worst. Meantime the adults at the Australian Energy Market Operator are doing their darnedest to make wind, solar, hydro and gas work for the benefit of the nation. No thanks to the pollies.Phil KreveldCaulfield, VicMusk seeks free speechThe Australian Financial Review's reporting on the battle between Elon Musk and the Australian political class is some of the most biased I have read.Freedom of speech is more important than anything any of us could do for Australia, including the prime minister. There is no public safety without it. There is no democracy without it. It is the basis of our social cohesion.The political class, egged on by the media, is trying to rule over the global internet here, even as Mr Musk has unwillingly complied with Australian legal directives while the matter is before the courts. Should videos of the September 11 attacks be censored? Or the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki? Those who censor rewrite history for malicious purpose.Stop and think for a second about the implications of what you are advocating.Remy ChadwickWagga Wagga, NSWTruth of super taxAll the heat and fury aimed at the Labor proposal to tax super fund balances above $3 million needs to be balanced against the reality as revealed in John Wasilev's column ("How will $3m super tax work when my balance rises and falls?", April 27-28).The bottom line as detailed in the response is that a $4 million super fund will pay Division 296 tax of a tad over $4000 a year. Using a conservative 7 per cent annual return, the $4 million fund should earn $280,000 a year. Tax of $4000 on this annual income amounts to a rate of 1.4 per cent. This is still significantly less than the tax a 20-year-old apprentice would pay on his or her meagre earnings.The fairer solution is to tax all retirement incomes at the same rate as other earnings after giving a generous allowance.Barry CookMitcham, SAA hollow promiseAt last some good news from Rowan Dean, who wrote: "Thanks to Anthony Albanese I am now out of a job" ("Seriously, Albo's meme theme is putting comedians out of work", April 27-28). Alas, like all of Dean's oeuvre, it was an unamusing falsehood detached from observable reality. What a shame.Chris RoylancePaddington, Qld
